subject: internal_client: Don't retry when we expect the same reponse
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-16 18:02:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-16 19:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This looks to me doing the opposite of what it purports to intend.

I read the intent as "do not continuously retry 404 and 412 because the objects aren't coming back in such a case".

Previously: the delete_actual_object() tried 3 times, returned; delete_object() did pop_queue()

Now: delete_actual_object() does not retry, but delete_object() receives UnexpectedResponse(), hits the reclaim_age check and re-raises without pop_queue(), so we're getting the same request and try to re-delete later endlessly for a week.

This seems worse than trying to delete 3 times.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-16 19:55:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think we can do *something* to improve how we retry - but the answer probably has something to do with x-backend-timestamp

If we get a 412, but the x-backend-timestamp is after when our expirer row was created it means we're an out-dated/overwritten row and we can delete (but we have to watch out... we just be getting a stale read, the object x-delete-at doesn't match *yet* but it might eventually)

If we get a 404 and the x-backend-timestmap is *after* our x-delete-at we're not going to make anything more correct by doing our delete (but we have to watch out for 404 on a missing object, or an x-backend-timestamp *before* our x-delete-at since there may yet still be a .data file out there that matches our x-delete-at)"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-16 20:05:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Previously: the delete_actual_object() tried 3 times, returned; delete_object() did pop_queue()

Nope -- we'd retry three times, sure, but then we'd still raise UnexpectedResponse (because it's not 2xx) and thus not issue a pop_queue.

> so we're getting the same request and try to re-delete later endlessly for a week.

Yep. I'm aiming for minimally-invasive, just trying to not do it 3x every time for the whole week.

> If we get a 412, but the x-backend-timestamp is after when our expirer row was created

> If we get a 404 and the x-backend-timestmap is *after* our x-delete-at

Shouldn't both of those 409? Object-server has newer info than our request timestamp."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-16 20:29:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

(2 comments)

Ok, I mis-scored - I didn't even understand what this change was doing.

I'm going to see if there is a more obvious way to tell make_request not to retry on 400 series requests instead of telling it to consider 400 series requests success just so we can convert them back into errors..."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-16 20:39:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Nope -- we'd retry three times, sure, but then we'd still raise
 > UnexpectedResponse (because it's not 2xx) and thus not issue a
 > pop_queue.

Oh. Okay, then... Why is it that you aren't squashing it into the big patch for the expirer?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-16 21:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-16 21:21:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

OK, broadening this to all of InternalClient. Guys that use that:

- expirer -- what prompted me to do this in the first place
- container sync -- already lists 4xx as acceptable
- container reconciler -- ...has a bunch of call sites, at least one of which should surely be accepting 409s. The others... I'm pretty sure retrying would just get the same response."}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-16 21:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-01-17 09:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I found 2 issues on this change.

A) the change on the reconstructor to set 409 as acceptable response is not tested even it looks ok though.

B) a test in the test_object_expirer.py looks odd because it looks to assert a response code which is never returned from object-server in the case of object-expierer.

I added several comments as inline. Please check them in detail. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-17 20:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-17 20:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-17 20:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-17 22:12:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Kota was right, I was not attentive enough. But still, looks okay. Now all eyes on the big patch for the expirer.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-18 00:24:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Even if we resolve the merge conflicts in the import path, the new test in the conflicted patch is being failure. [1] is an approach to fix the problem.

1: https://gist.github.com/bloodeagle40234/05946f156cfdbeebfb6da3320c59d858'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-18 18:18:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

still fine'}, {'account_id': 4608, 'date': '2018-01-19 02:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

LGTM, thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-19 02:35:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(8 comments)

I'm mostly fine, but concerned/confused by our special case of 409... where we retry... but only sometimes... if you pull this one string... that seems unrelated... but might be useful... 

I probably just need to be educated; but I would assume the obvious thing [1] is correct and more maintainable.

1. https://review.openstack.org/535575"}]

This means, among other things, that the expirer won't issue 3 DELETEs

commit_message:
internal_client: Don't retry when we expect the same reponse

This boils down to 404, 412, or 416; or 409 when we provided an
X-Timestamp.

This means, among other things, that the expirer won't issue 3 DELETEs
every cycle for every stale work item.

Related-Change: Icd63c80c73f864d2561e745c3154fbfda02bd0cc
Change-Id: Ie5f2d3824e040bbc76d511a54d1316c4c2503732

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-18 02:20:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix openstackdocstheme options for api-ref

Initialize the parameter for current openstackdocstheme so that report a
bug feature works and displays all parameter including git URL and SHA.

We need to add openstackdocstheme as extension so that the parameter are
properly initialized. html_context is not needed anymore. The display of
time of last commit is done by openstackdocstheme.

Closes-Bug: #1743728
Change-Id: Ide3233132810328a99ac8edbfb72ebd5ee3e2492
'}]
commit_message:
Fix openstackdocstheme options for api-ref

Initialize the parameter for current openstackdocstheme so that report a
bug feature works and displays all parameter including git URL and SHA.

We need to add openstackdocstheme as extension so that the parameter are
properly initialized. html_context is not needed anymore. The display of
time of last commit is done by openstackdocstheme.

Closes-Bug: #1743728
Change-Id: Ide3233132810328a99ac8edbfb72ebd5ee3e2492

messages:
[{'account_id': 27641, 'date': '2018-01-15 03:59:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-15 03:59:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack. Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it. People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch and resubmit a new change-set. Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base. Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you. IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-01-15 05:24:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1 (1 comment) Great, thanks for this Cheng! And thank you so much for submitting something to Swift. I like it, but I think we can save an additional request to the cluster (see in line). Also based on the time of your commit, your in APAC too. go team APAC! ;)'}, {'account_id': 27641, 'date': '2018-01-15 05:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 comment) > (1 comment) > > Great, thanks for this Cheng! And thank you so much for submitting > something to Swift. > > I like it, but I think we can save an additional request to the > cluster (see in line). > > Also based on the time of your commit, your in APAC too. go team > APAC! ;) Thanks for your review. I will fix it in the next patch. And yes, I am in China.'}, {'account_id': 27641, 'date': '2018-01-15 06:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-16 21:41:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 so this works: BEFORE: ubuntu@saio:~$ curl -H 'x-auth-token: AUTH_tk83b075a0bae44c85b0b344a01de843e9' http://saio:8080/v1/AUTH_test/test -XPUT -v * Trying 127.0.0.1... * Connected to saio (127.0.0.1) port 8080 (#0) > PUT /v1/AUTH_test/test HTTP/1.1 > Host: saio:8080 > User-Agent: curl/7.47.0 > Accept: */* > x-auth-token: AUTH_tk83b075a0bae44c85b0b344a01de843e9 > < HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found < Content-Length: 70 < Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 < X-Trans-Id: txe1e0f2273514419387c8e-005a5e701f < X-Openstack-Request-Id: txe1e0f2273514419387c8e-005a5e701f < Date: Tue, 16 Jan 2018 21:35:27 GMT < * Connection #0 to host saio left intact

Not Found

The resource could not be found.

AFTER: ubuntu@saio:~$ curl -H 'x-auth-token: AUTH_tk83b075a0bae44c85b0b344a01de843e9' http://saio:8080/v1/AUTH_test/test -XPUT -v * Trying 127.0.0.1... * Connected to saio (127.0.0.1) port 8080 (#0) > PUT /v1/AUTH_test/test HTTP/1.1 > Host: saio:8080 > User-Agent: curl/7.47.0 > Accept: */* > x-auth-token: AUTH_tk83b075a0bae44c85b0b344a01de843e9 > < HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Error < Content-Length: 125 < Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8 < X-Trans-Id: tx7412e514baf94ab296dd3-005a5e7044 < X-Openstack-Request-Id: tx7412e514baf94ab296dd3-005a5e7044 < Date: Tue, 16 Jan 2018 21:36:04 GMT < * Connection #0 to host saio left intact

Internal Error

The server has either erred or is incapable of performing the requested operation.

that's got to be worth *something* - the code looks fine... i'm not unsurprised the test changes were so trivial. It'll be nice to get this fixed I think. I can't imagine how a client could possibly have been expecting this behavior... in all cases this condition has to be a misconfiguration/deployment issue? To demonstrate the bad status code I had just pre-created my accounts dirs on my saio with the wrong permissions: for d in $(ls -d /mnt/swift-disk/sdb*); do sudo mkdir $d/accounts; done Then later fixed them.. for d in $(ls -d /mnt/swift-disk/sdb*/accounts); do sudo chown ubuntu:ubuntu $d; done /me shrugs"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-18 21:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1 (1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-18 22:32:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 comment) I'd +2 503 too"}, {'account_id': 27641, 'date': '2018-01-19 01:38:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 comment) > (1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-19 01:51:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2 Server error is server error -- it's gotta be better than what we've got currently."}, {'account_id': 27399, 'date': '2018-01-19 03:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}]

commit_message:
Return HTTPServerError instead of HTTPNotFound

Swift allows autocreate account. It should be treat as server error
instead of 404 when it fails to create account

Change-Id: I726271bc06e3c1b07a4af504c3fd7ddb789bd512
Closes-bug: 1718810

commit_message:
Remove link to Stack

Panel for Stack, i.e. Heat Dashboard, was separated to
independent UI Plugin.
So we should remove link to Stack panel on details view
for Cluster.

Change-Id: I15e32b28e54c9b7f8f9fec03870b012cb3141726

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 02:49:49.000000000', 'message': 'Zuul: add file extension to playbook path

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

Change-Id: I23dad7fcc4f525bde28b7bf1a43b9a2d353a377b
(cherry picked from commit 6f7d24c40cc91b84104d0336ee7943d6c07ddb59)
'}]
commit_message:
Zuul: add file extension to playbook path

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

Change-Id: I23dad7fcc4f525bde28b7bf1a43b9a2d353a377b
(cherry picked from commit 6f7d24c40cc91b84104d0336ee7943d6c07ddb59)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-12 18:44:57.000000000', 'message': "Remove metric service

There is discussion on the mailing list about ceilometerclient removal
that started this.

The metric service is not an OpenStack service. It does not have an
entry in service-types-authority, nor does it have an API documented at
developer.openstack.org/api-ref.

That's not saying that someone couldn't install it in their OpenStack
cloud and that doing so is a bad idea. It's probably a great idea and
those people are likely quite happy.

Since this is openstacksdk we need to draw the line somewhere. The
add_service patch adds the ability for consumers to opt-in to
non-official services. Making an openstacksdk-metric package people
could use with a MetricService object and the proxy/resource objects
here would be a great idea.

As a follow-up we should potentially add the ability to add a list of
extra services to a clouds.yaml file.

Change-Id: Ib3810e3b11dbacc0215d486397e05370a2d7521e

developer.openstack.org/api-ref.

That's not saying that someone couldn't install it in their OpenStack
cloud and that doing so is a bad idea. It's probably a great idea and
those people are likely quite happy.

Since this is openstacksdk we need to draw the line somewhere. The
add_service patch adds the ability for consumers to opt-in to
non-official services. Making an openstacksdk-metric package people
could use with a MetricService object and the proxy/resource objects
here would be a great idea.

As a follow-up we should potentially add the ability to add a list of
extra services to a clouds.yaml file.

Change-Id: Ib3810e3b11dbacc0215d486397e05370a2d7521e
"}]
commit_message:
Remove metric service

There is discussion on the mailing list about ceilometerclient removal
that started this.

The metric service is not an OpenStack service. It does not have an
entry in service-types-authority, nor does it have an API documented at
developer.openstack.org/api-ref.

That's not saying that someone couldn't install it in their OpenStack
cloud and that doing so is a bad idea. It's probably a great idea and
those people are likely quite happy.

Since this is openstacksdk we need to draw the line somewhere. The
add_service patch adds the ability for consumers to opt-in to
non-official services. Making an openstacksdk-metric package people
could use with a MetricService object and the proxy/resource objects
here would be a great idea.

As a follow-up we should potentially add the ability to add a list of
extra services to a clouds.yaml file.

Change-Id: Ib3810e3b11dbacc0215d486397e05370a2d7521e

commit_message:
Mark Newton as EOL in releases documentation

Newton is EOL, but we have not updated the release table, so it still
shows up as active. This updates the release to show its final state.

Change-Id: Iceb608eb962d98d51ed11184f7450feb9101dc0f

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-14 20:38:44.000000000', 'message': "gnocchi/ceilometer upgrade workflow fix

The current workflow for gnocchi/ceilometer upgrade doesn't
work well with swift backend.

Notification agent push data into Gnocchi on step4, but
Ceilometer-upgrade run only on step5, So Gnocchi have not been populated
with latest resource schemas.

Gnocchi-api is started in step3 but gnocchi::storage configuration have
not been done and database upgrade have not been done.

This change will fix this issue by:

* Doing only the Gnocchi database upgrade on step3.
* Configuring gnocchi::storage on step3.
* Doing the remaining storage/incoming upgrade of Gnocchi on step4 when
  swift is ready.
* We can do ceilometer-upgrade at step4, without waiting for swift to
  be ready

This ensures:

* gnocchi-api will be correctly configured at the end of
  step3 (configuration+database-sync).
* No new measures will be pushed to Gnocchi before ceilometer-upgrade have
  upgraded the Gnocchi resource schemas.
* Gnocchi-api have database updated before ceilometer-upgrade need it.
* We continue to upgrade storage/incoming data of Gnocchi on step4 after
  swift is up.

Closes-bug: #1724328
Change-Id: I3f9a784e507e03454b335ba8319601fba208ba0a
(cherry picked from commit 4e6939c1a874a06f336321a9d44d9991872f74cf)

commit_message:
gnocchi/ceilometer upgrade workflow fix

The current workflow for gnocchi/ceilometer upgrade doesn't
work well with swift backend.

Notification agent push data into Gnocchi on step4, but
Ceilometer-upgrade run only on step5, So Gnocchi have not been populated
with latest resource schemas.

Gnocchi-api is started in step3 but gnocchi::storage configuration have
not been done and database upgrade have not been done.

When configuration is done on step4, httpd will be restarted.

This change will fix this issue by:

* Doing only the Gnocchi database upgrade on step3 because swift is
  ready only on step4.
* Configuring gnocchi::storage on step3 to avoid gnocchi-api restart on
  step4.
* Move ceilometer-notification on step4 to ensure ceilometer-upgrade
  have been run.

This ensures:

* gnocchi-api will be correctly configured at the end of
  step3 (configuration+database-sync).
* No new measures will be pushed to Gnocchi before ceilometer-upgrade have
  upgraded the Gnocchi resource schemas.
* Gnocchi-api have database updated before ceilometer-upgrade need it.
* We continue to upgrade storage/incoming data of Gnocchi on step4 after
  swift is up.

Closes-bug: #1724328
Change-Id: I3f9a784e507e03454b335ba8319601fba208ba0a
(cherry picked from commit 4e6939c1a874a06f336321a9d44d9991872f74cf)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-12 18:44:57.000000000', 'message': "Remove meter service

As per the mailing list thread on ceilometerclient, the REST API for
ceilometer has been long deprecated and is now completely unsupported.

Remove the meter service and its sub-service alarm.

On the one hand, it's a REST API so there is no need for us to not
support it. As a general rule removing support for services that we have
already is a bad thing.

On the other hand, we haven't cut the 1.0 yet, and as ceilometer doesn't
exist anymore we can't really do devstack testing of it.

The previous patch adds support for out-of-tree services. So anyone who
cares about the 'meter' service can grab this, port it to Proxy2 and
then do an add_service.

Change-Id: Ic226c5ac048ba09e316c89cae1e8f2828e753e80

commit_message:
Remove meter service

As per the mailing list thread on ceilometerclient, the REST API for
ceilometer has been long deprecated and is now completely unsupported.

Remove the meter service and its sub-service alarm.

On the one hand, it's a REST API so there is no need for us to not
support it. As a general rule removing support for services that we have
already is a bad thing.

On the other hand, we haven't cut the 1.0 yet, and as ceilometer doesn't
exist anymore we can't really do devstack testing of it.

The previous patch adds support for out-of-tree services. So anyone who
cares about the 'meter' service can grab this, port it to Proxy2 and
then do an add_service.

Change-Id: Ic226c5ac048ba09e316c89cae1e8f2828e753e80

commit_message:
Do not override stage-dir in tempest post

Stage dir used to be /opt/stack but now devstack changed to
use ansible user dir as a stage dir (which is the default
value) so the override is not needed anymore.

Change-Id: Id531271da326413c5a88947d9a8b3ac4da68c47d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-05 16:30:25.000000000', 'message': 'PyMySQL 0.8.0 compat fix

In PyMySQL the "MULTI_STATEMENT" flag has been disabled
by default. (see PyMySQL/PyMySQL#590 )

Migration 98 had a single string with multiple statements
ran in a single execution.

Moving this to multiple executions of the same statements
allows the migration to succeed with the new behaviour.

Caused-By: PyMySQL/PyMySQL@c0aa3179406571592d3beb9d5a35badc4047cb79

Change-Id: I5f6d92f695c4c5830b8595b0cecbbafb426470a1
'}]
commit_message:
PyMySQL 0.8.0 compat fix

In PyMySQL the "MULTI_STATEMENT" flag has been disabled
by default. (see PyMySQL/PyMySQL#590 )

Migration 98 had a single string with multiple statements
ran in a single execution.

Moving this to multiple executions of the same statements
allows the migration to succeed with the new behaviour.

Caused-By: PyMySQL/PyMySQL@c0aa3179406571592d3beb9d5a35badc4047cb79

Change-Id: I5f6d92f695c4c5830b8595b0cecbbafb426470a1

commit_message:
Install redis 3.2 for fedora22

I think our existing code can only be installed in fedora redis2.8,
and our latest is to support redis3.2. These conclusions are only
tested in the virtual machine, there is no guarantee that the
image built with this will be available.

Closes-Bug: #1743526
Change-Id: I355384348f2b6b02f8fd41e0cc0d62b975e24359

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-12 15:33:18.000000000', 'message': 'Shift additional_user_agent in the stack

The additional_user_agent is intended for things, such as
os-client-config, that sit somewhere in the stack between keystoneauth
and the actual client. So according to jamielennox in irc, it should be:

  app client *additional_user_agent keystoneauth requests

The current logic puts additional_user_agent between app and client,
leading to things that look like this:

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 shade/1.19.1
   keystoneauth1/2.18.0 python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

Which is a bit off.

Change-Id: Iddfbeab322a39d3ba893a15aabb4c79050526451
'}, {'created': '2017-12-22 13:22:28.000000000', 'message': 'Shift additional_user_agent in the stack

and the actual client. So according to jamielennox in irc, it should be:

The current logic puts additional_user_agent between app and client,
leading to things that look like this:

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 shade/1.19.1
   keystoneauth1/2.18.0 python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

Which is a bit off.

Change-Id: Iddfbeab322a39d3ba893a15aabb4c79050526451
'}]
commit_message:
Shift additional_user_agent in the stack

The additional_user_agent is intended for things, such as
os-client-config, that sit somewhere in the stack between keystoneauth
and the actual client. So according to jamielennox in irc, it should be:

  app client *additional_user_agent keystoneauth requests

The current logic puts additional_user_agent between app and client,
leading to things that look like this:

  "User-Agent: v.py/1 os-client-config/1.26.1 shade/1.19.1
   keystoneauth1/2.18.0 python-requests/2.13.0 CPython/2.7.12"

Which is a bit off.

Change-Id: Iddfbeab322a39d3ba893a15aabb4c79050526451

commit_message:
Zuul: add file extension to playbook path

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

Change-Id: I23dad7fcc4f525bde28b7bf1a43b9a2d353a377b
(cherry picked from commit 6f7d24c40cc91b84104d0336ee7943d6c07ddb59)

commit_message:
Java persister config: defaults and robustness

This commit adds defaults for configuration settings where
that makes sense so they can be omitted. Likewise, unknown
settings will now be ignored everywhere except for the
database sections (the relevant configuration classes for that
are in monasca-common).

Change-Id: I35ae02e44a11e088c36943d8c053aac07dbe7524
Story: 2001415
Task: 6115

subject: Allow for object uploads > 5GB from stdin.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2017-06-28 22:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(9 comments)

I think this is going to be great.

I think there's essentially two issues that could make this feature do "the right amount" of cleanup while primarily adding this feature.

1) add docstrings to the new helper/static methods that you are either currently reusing, or you would expect/like to see re-used in the future.
2) have those docstrings say *anything else* besides:

    :returns: a dict, generally speaking, it represents a response "object" of
              sorts if you will, but it will contain some random set of keys that
              are arbitrarily consistent with other places you might encounter a
              thing that "feels" like a response "object" + whatever else seems
              convenient at the moment.

^ because that is BS, not your *fault* - but the bar is *so low* you could raise it with very little effort - and even just *attempting* would get people excited about not only this change/feature - but about merging a pattern that gives hope of a better future.  I don't know if the answer is to define a minimum set of keys in a response dict?  Or to make a response dict factory, or a response object class that has a to_dict method for legacy compat?  No idea.  I guess even just an example that explicitly enumerates the keys could be good enough... even if it's likely to rust.

IMHO, that'd be enough.  You should not for example try and track down all of the places that should be using your new _put_object and fix them (although that will be super easy once it has a properly structured and documented API!) because that'd be orthogonal to what this change is trying to accomplish at best, and a distraction slowing down users getting their grubby hands on stdin SLO upload (SO AWESOME!!111!) at worst.

But you also shouldn't *avoid* method extracting code you want to re-use just to avoid having to think about the interface and writing a doc string - you want to reuse it?  GREAT!  But make it's re-useable for the next guy too.  IMHO.

If you added tests this change might be good enough to merge as is - we can always improve doc-o in follow up changes.  I only did the most barebones functional testing - it seems *mostly* fine.

I feel like normally segmented uploads output noise to the console after each segment gets uploaded - I sort miss that.

I also feel like something something unicode?

    ubuntu@saio:/vagrant/.scratch$ cat testme.builder | swift upload test - --object-name junk.test -S 100000
    'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x80 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)'}, {'account_id': 9216, 'date': '2017-07-05 19:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks Timur. I like what's going on here - I'll try to do some functional testing asap, but the approach looks fine :)"}, {'account_id': 17363, 'date': '2017-07-07 23:22:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

One thing that I realized bothers me a little is that there is no way to express "Upload from stdin, but don't use the SLO -- I know the object will be < 5GB", because there is no "do not use SLO" option. It may be a corner case, but I think it would be great to address it as well.

Thanks for the comments Clay -- I will try to address them and work on writing up the tests.'}, {'account_id': 17363, 'date': '2017-07-15 00:29:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17363, 'date': '2017-07-15 00:32:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

It does what we're looking for... but I'm worried about:

- the lack of visibility into what's been uploaded when we're doing an SLO (maybe just log segments as we upload them, like we do for normal SLOs?,
- the non-obviousness of what to do when you only have access to the one container (*either* increase -S that you didn't set *or* include --segment-container pointing to the same container), and
- the extra container PUT even when we're just going to upload an ordinary object (seems like we ought to be able to avoid this?)

Also irksome, but way down in priority:

- empty dict in default args (general hygiene),
- TODO that I don't understand what's required for it to be TODONE, and
- duplicate checks for single-object-ness."}, {'account_id': 17363, 'date': '2017-07-25 23:35:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

This seems like violating the KISS principle with a chainsaw. If you want the buffering reduced, why not to upload chunked?'}, {'account_id': 17363, 'date': '2017-08-18 17:58:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

The goal is not reducing buffering itself, but support uploads from stdin that may be larger than 5 GB. Since the input stream is of unknown size, the patch attempts to check whether it should be a single object upload or an SLO. This follows a similar approach in AWS CLI: https://github.com/aws/aws-cli/pull/903.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2017-08-18 19:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

(9 comments)

Still need to look at tests... but playing around with it on the CLI seems promising; no obvious fence-post issues, and the zero-byte object issue's cleared up:

 $ dd if=/dev/zero bs=100 count=3 2>/dev/null | swift upload c - --object-name o -S 99 && swift list c_segments -l | awk '{print $1, $5}' && swift download -o - c o | wc -c && swift delete c o
 o segment 0
 o segment 1
 o segment 2
 o segment 3
 o

 99 o/slo/1503082593.000000/99/00000002
 3 o/slo/1503082593.000000/99/00000003

 300
 o

Zero-byte object is still a little weird, though:

 o segment 0
 o

Why report it twice?"}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2017-08-19 04:44:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

[{'created': '2017-06-28 19:05:13.000000000', 'message': 'Turn stdin uploads in SLO above 10MB.

If the Standard Input upload exceeds 10MB, we should turn it into an
SLO. Below 10MB, a single object is uploaded. This limits the amount
of buffering done when reading from a stream to 10MB. This is actually
tunable as up to 1 segment is buffered, so setting segment-size to a
higher value allows for larger single object uploads from stdin.

This is a WIP patch. I wanted to share the change before adding tests.

Change-Id: Ib13e0b687bc85930c29fe9f151cf96bc53b2e594

commit_message:
Allow for object uploads > 5GB from stdin.

When uploading from standard input, swiftclient should turn the upload
into an SLO in the case of large objects. This patch picks the
threshold as 10MB (and uses that as the default segment size). The
consumers can also supply the --segment-size option to alter that
threshold and the SLO segment size. The patch does buffer one segment
in memory (which is why 10MB default was chosen).

(test is updated)

Change-Id: Ib13e0b687bc85930c29fe9f151cf96bc53b2e594

commit_message:
Revert "Add Constraints support"

Per http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125348.html

> For many projects, tox_install.sh is not needed at all

Let's see if that holds for python-swiftclient!

This reverts commit f2f278fcbec3ad52a1726bb5a3f775d13bcc99dc.

Change-Id: I0462c50ec71d87bac226f83a0d0942871ef5a0e7

[{'account_id': 23314, 'date': '2018-01-17 09:19:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-01-18 10:52:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

Thank you for having interest to translation.
However translation is working in i18n team for each language using Zanata. Horizon and Plugin projects are only applying patches from Zanata. So we don't create patches for translation (.po files) directly in each dashboard projects.
Could you access i18n team for Chinese? Please see follow.
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/I18nTeam/team/zh_cn"}, {'account_id': 23314, 'date': '2018-01-19 01:25:27.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Fix api-ref for v3 volume types

This patch dome some fixs on api-ref for v3 volume types, including:

1. add api-ref and sample file for show default volume type API
2. remove unused sample file: volume-type-show-request.json
3. fix parameters: 'name', 'extra_specs', 'is_public', 'description',
and 'os-volume-type-access:is_public'

Change-Id: I6fdcb66d3a56643a5e71bcd68f4bcdc08fc4866b

commit_message:
Import midonet config in each service driver

This allows midonet plugins to be specified in any order
and not have to worry about import orders. Currently
some drivers could be loaded without the midonet config being
registered with oslo_config.

Change-Id: I1f62228437d1c27bd35c2df1dc9364297591eaf5
Closes-Bug: #1729751
(cherry picked from commit 8e0cb044be5845d4033e3a11c688adad580a877a)
Conflicts:
    midonet/neutron/services/firewall/plugin.py
    midonet/neutron/services/l2gateway/service_drivers/l2gw_midonet.py
    midonet/neutron/services/taas/service_drivers/taas_midonet.py
    midonet/neutron/services/vpn/service_drivers/midonet_ipsec.py

commit_message:
Correct keystone-doctor tag name

Running keystone-doctor should only be done in the
config stage. It makes no sense to run when using
any other tag in isolation.

commit_message:
Fix sources-branch-updater and add docs

Problems resolved:

- Errors relating to 'etc' folders which did not exist in the
  target repositories have been eliminated.

- Some repositories were not being excluded from evaluation
  for file/template updates. All appropriate exclusions are
  now implemented.

- If an OSA role repository did not have the required folder
  to copy rootwrap files into, the copy would fail and the
  rootwrap files therefore be left out of the patch.

- When executed on Mac OS X, python2 is not found.

It also adds documentation for how to use the script to handle
the periodic SHA bumps.

Change-Id: I628cd2c3156d118c17ca2f90d4ccf0bc5a080bbf

commit_message:
[arch-guide] Correct paragraph about vertical upgrades in compute

Added more clarity to paragraph and deleted any sentence fragments
that didn't make sense. This clarifies the point of rolling upgrades
for vertical scaling of individual compute nodes.

commit_message:
rehome plugin utils

This patch rehomes a bulk of neutron.plugins.common.utils into
neutron-lib. What's left in the neutron plugin utils will be made
private upon consumption.

In addition this patch also enhances the is_valid_* functions of
the utils to ensure the range value is a number. The previous
implementation allowed passing boolean values for tunnel ranges.

UTs and a release note are also included.

For a sample consumption patch see
Ifcb39c08706d7a12f3ebd5865eb6d2edb95eed45

Change-Id: Iabb155b5d2d0ec6104ebee5dd42cf292bdf3ec61

commit_message:
Import midonet config in each service driver

This allows midonet plugins to be specified in any order
and not have to worry about import orders. Currently
some drivers could be loaded without the midonet config being
registered with oslo_config.

Change-Id: I1f62228437d1c27bd35c2df1dc9364297591eaf5
Closes-Bug: #1729751
(cherry picked from commit 8e0cb044be5845d4033e3a11c688adad580a877a)

commit_message:
Release os-brick 2.3.0

This release is for the Queens non-client library freeze.

The release includes a number of changes from dependency
changes to adding support for additional transports for
iSCSI.  As a result this justified a feature bump.

Change-Id: Ieec618853e2f57760718809de50cf681f9515719

'}, {'created': '2017-07-26 00:39:38.000000000', 'message': 'grenade: For multi-node grenade, do not upgrade nova

Multi-node grenade jobs will fail if we upgrade nova as the minimum
required API for nova to communicate with ironic was upgraded.

Our goal for multi-node grenade is to test rolling upgrades. The
scenario we envision for rolling upgrades to be done is:

 1) Upgrade ironic-conductor services one by one. This means old
    ironic-api services communicating with new and old
    ironic-conductor services. This is what the multi-node grenade job
    tests.
 2) Upgrade ironic-api services.
 3) Upgrade nova

In this upgrade procedure we should not be running updated nova with
old ironic-api services. This patch fixes that.

Closes-Bug: #1706418
Change-Id: I85c607ae7d031e4cabcb505915aca7e88df166aa
'}]
commit_message:
grenade: For multi-node grenade, do not upgrade nova

Multi-node grenade jobs will fail if we upgrade nova as the minimum
required API for nova to communicate with ironic was upgraded.

Our goal for multi-node grenade is to test rolling upgrades. The
scenario we envision for rolling upgrades to be done is:

 1) Upgrade ironic-conductor services one by one. This means old
    ironic-api services communicating with new and old
    ironic-conductor services. This is what the multi-node grenade job
    tests.
 2) Upgrade ironic-api services.
 3) Upgrade nova

In this upgrade procedure we should not be running updated nova with
old ironic-api services. This patch fixes that.

Closes-Bug: #1706418
Change-Id: I85c607ae7d031e4cabcb505915aca7e88df166aa

commit_message:
Keep object-updater stats logging consistent

If we're going to encapsulate the stats tracking it seems reasonable if
we ever add any more metrics we can reduce the number of places we need
to update log messages.

Change-Id: I187cf6cfec1e0a9138b709fa298e1991aa809ec4

What do you think Lance?"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-01-12 10:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 29.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-01-12 12:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30: Patch Set 29 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-01-12 22:27:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 31: Patch Set 30 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-01-13 21:13:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 32.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-01-16 00:16:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 32: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add Application Credentials manager

Add the manager layer for application credentials. This handles
generating CADF notifications on create/delete and listening for
notifications that affect application credentials' lifetime. On create,
the manager keeps a copy of the initial secret so that it may be
returned to the user, but it is otherwise never stored. The secret hash
is stored and must be filtered out before being returned to the user.

bp application-credentials

Change-Id: Iae6377e78d2b8e15472d378ef54e29a946dc51b5

commit_message:
Add system role assignment documentation

Hot off the press! This commit contains all the API reference
documentation for using system role assignments. It is also
consistent with the api-reference conventions we established
during the Queens PTG in Denver.

bp system-scope

commit_message:
Speed up trunk MTU enforcement check

While things may have become generally slower for reasons still
to be determined at the time this patch was developed, we noticed
that enforcing MTU rules between subports and trunk parent was
done by performing one DB lookup per subport. This patch optmizes
the performance by piggybacking on the logic that is used to
retrieve the subport underlying network's segmentation type when
the segmentation type must be inherited.

Closes-bug: #1741954

Change-Id: Ib18427ef7a3509088eaf8fa0cfed3fb659b6baea
(cherry picked from commit d23a9ad7313b6d4b275f3b46c89d9f79d3cfb9a4)

commit_message:
Move to tenacity for url request retry

openstack/ceilometer moved to using tenacity instead of retrying
back in November 2016.  See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/398641/

To stay in sync with Ceilometer, make the same change here.

Change-Id: Iccdd8895d54e9373e77294827b564cd04e28dea2

commit_message:
Add correlation type "nsh" to both PPs and PCs

Add correlation type "nsh" to both Port Pair and Port Create
commands' help descriptions.

The NSH correlation/encapsulation has been added to networking-sfc
and this patch makes the client show the option in the help description.

Change-Id: Ib25d24cd05e994b7865641a8235d36c741533488
Partial-Bug: #1625278

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > The neutron client should have a method 'find_extension' that
 > permits to check if an extension is supported by interrogated API.
 > You could check if 'bgpvpn-vni' is supported before append the
 > argument to commands.

It would make sense, but on the other hand this does not seem to be done anywhere in python-neutronclient, at least in OSC code (e.g. it's not done for the base bgpvpn CLI code).

I think this should be addressed separately and done consistently across all extension (need to create a LP bug to discuss/track this)."}, {'account_id': 25171, 'date': '2017-09-26 05:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-26 07:33:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

commit_message:
Autospeccing: NVRAM

This continues the effort to autospec throughout the project. It covers
the NVRAM tests. This will help catch errors in argument lists, object
attributes, and other possible issues.

Change-Id: I01361bf3deb8e34d2e1841794d721c4d95d565fe

commit_message:
Autospeccing: Tasks

This adds autospeccing throughout the tasks tests. This will help catch
errors in argument lists, object attributes, and other possible issues.
This is the first of a series of patches for autospeccing throughout
the project.

Change-Id: I93719a3c9569e59f9b7443b7407f4c2ab026a919

commit_message:
Add cluster-instances to OSC

This change adds database support for the python-openstackclient
project for the cluster-instances command.

The trove command cluster-instances is now:
    openstack database cluster list instances

Change-Id: Ifcbb0a0374d4b2918ee22b85a0733c8bbbf21497
Partially-Implements: blueprint trove-support-in-python-openstackclient
Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

update'}, {'account_id': 22608, 'date': '2018-01-18 03:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

There are two resize command resize instance and resize volume.
My suggestion is use "openstack database instance resize flavor" and "openstack database instance resize volume".
Besides, you should run the command in your local, then you will find that "openstack database resize instance" doesn't exist.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-01-18 05:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > There are two resize command resize instance and resize volume.
 > My suggestion is use "openstack database instance resize flavor"
 > and "openstack database instance resize volume".
 > Besides, you should run the command in your local, then you will
 > find that "openstack database resize instance" doesn't exist.

And the pep8 check should also be done in the local dev enviornment first.'}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-01-18 05:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-01-18 05:41:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

In troveclient 'resize-instance' and 'resize-volume' are two commands, however they are calling methods from the same Instance manager, so it's better to build osc commands like what zhanggang mentioned: 'database instance resize flavor' and 'database instance resize volume', or to make the subcommand shorter, we could go with 'database instance resize' and make '--flavor' and '--volume' as two exclusive arguments."}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-01-18 05:59:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> In troveclient 'resize-instance' and 'resize-volume' are two
 > commands, however they are calling methods from the same Instance
 > manager, so it's better to build osc commands like what zhanggang
 > mentioned: 'database instance resize flavor' and 'database instance
 > resize volume', or to make the subcommand shorter, we could go with
 > 'database instance resize' and make '--flavor' and '--volume' as
 > two exclusive arguments.

thanks for great reviewing. Yes, i notice that. I prefer what zhanggang metioned, and separate resize-flavor and resize-volume to two command."}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-01-18 06:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-01-18 08:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Others look good to me.'}, {'account_id': 22608, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

run `tox` before you commit.  For example, just test PEP8 use `tox -epep8`'}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> run `tox` before you commit.  For example, just test PEP8 use `tox
 > -epep8`

i have run pycodestyle instead of pep8 before push, maybe i need run pep8 again.'}, {'account_id': 27577, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:36:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-01-18 11:49:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 22818, 'date': '2018-01-18 17:34:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add resize-instance to OSC

This change adds database support to the python-openstackclient
project for the resize-instance command

The trove command resize-instance is now:
    openstack database instance resize flavor

Change-Id: I58f8a6ebf8f715c5cc67ce67a36f87d720056ffe
Partially-Implements: blueprint trove-support-in-python-openstackclient

subject: Update dependencies
messages:
[{'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-01-17 13:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-01-17 15:12:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:00:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This fails lint for me locally with npm5.6.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:03:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's complaining about the eslint react rules missing.  I see that you fix that in the next patch.  I think we'll need to include that here or we won't pass CI."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:14:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, but do I understand it correctly that it should pass the CI since CI uses 'older' deps? Following patch should fix all testing and linting errors: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534760/2"}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:27:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Once this RDO patch merges, we can build a new version of openstack-tripleo-ui-deps (nodejs 8.9.4, npm 5.6.x).  Once that's available, we can recheck the "Upgrade prettier" patch, and all of its children.  When we get to this patch ("Update dependencies"), CI will fail because of the eslint definitions.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I don think so. 2 things:
1. new openstack-tripleo-ui-deps built with latest node is already done (8-4) [1]
2. IIUC once RDO patch lands, upstream CI will use 8-4 build and prettier patch will pass and merge. Then we rebuild ui-deps again and then the CI on all ui patches should pass, including the update dependencies one because the lint error is caused by updated dependency, but CI will at that time use ui-deps package which does not include these new dependencies. So CI will pass. Only requirement is that the patch which fixes lint errors gets merged then as it is the only one which will pass the CI at that moment

[1] http://cbs.centos.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=4136'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-01-18 00:53:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-01-18 00:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 10384, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

'}, {'created': '2018-01-04 12:04:37.000000000', 'message': 'support adding and deleting templates without the need to restart vitrage.

* templates are now stored in the database.
* evaluator is reloaded whenever a template is added/removed.
* supporting all types of templates (standard, equivalence, definition)
* new cli commands:
  - vitrage template add
  - vitrage template delete

Change-Id: I58abf5e034662206bd6919493c95c450c0ecdf9c
Depends-On: I07741ed100b9eb70b303567706b659d10a34b156

'}, {'created': '2018-01-08 09:25:08.000000000', 'message': 'support adding and deleting templates without the need to restart vitrage.

* templates are now stored in the database.
* evaluator is reloaded whenever a template is added/removed.
* supporting all types of templates (standard, equivalence, definition)
* new cli commands:
  - vitrage template add

commit_message:
support adding and deleting templates without the need to restart vitrage.

* templates are now stored in the database.
* evaluator is reloaded whenever a template is added/removed.
* supporting all types of templates (standard, equivalence, definition)
* new cli commands:
  - vitrage template add
  - vitrage template delete

Change-Id: I58abf5e034662206bd6919493c95c450c0ecdf9c
Depends-On: I07741ed100b9eb70b303567706b659d10a34b156
Implements: blueprint crud-templates

subject: slo: Send ETag header in 206 responses
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-12 22:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-17 00:11:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

+1 additive and backwards compatible enhancement - additional useful information provided this way is a win for sure!

Seems orthogonal to the javascript testing stuff, maybe update existing functional tests around here:

    diff --git a/test/functional/test_slo.py b/test/functional/test_slo.py
    index a4bcd8d..6634642 100644
    --- a/test/functional/test_slo.py
    +++ b/test/functional/test_slo.py
    @@ -348,6 +348,8 @@ class TestSlo(Base):
             file_item = self.env.container.file('manifest-abcde')
             file_contents = file_item.read(size=1024 * 1024 + 2,
                                            offset=1024 * 1024 - 1)
    +        self.assertEqual(file_item.conn.response.status, 206)
    +        self.assertIn('etag', dict(file_item.conn.response.getheaders()))
             self.assertEqual('a', file_contents[0])
             self.assertEqual('b', file_contents[1])
             self.assertEqual('b', file_contents[-2])

... and rebase this somewhere we can land it"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-17 19:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-01-17 23:32:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-01-18 00:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

still good'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-18 00:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I wonder if we could try to get ahold of dfg and ask about this?  Last I heard the hummingbird guys still ran swift functional tests against their troubling stuff...'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2018-01-18 16:10:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

hey- been a while since i've done this :) I don't know why it removed the Etag- if i was to guess maybe something it inherited from DLOs back in the day? Thanks for heads up about functests but looks like hummingbird already returns the Etag on SLO 206s so we should be good. I guess we missed that when porting it over.

As a side note- we've made a lot of progress on hummingbird last year. For anybody who want to try it out here's the dev install page: 

https://github.com/troubling/hummingbird/blob/master/HAIO.md

btw- it does fail some swift functests. We have to skip some of them that we can't, in some cases won't, fix. I'm making a note to add a script to run the paired down list for that init script. you can see what we run on our travis-ci here: 

https://github.com/troubling/hummingbird/blob/master/.travis.yml"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2018-01-18 18:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-12 22:54:07.000000000', 'message': "slo: Send ETag header in 206 responses

Why weren't we doing that before?? The etag shouldn't have changed, and
by sending it, we can assure resuming clients that they're downlading
the same object as before.

Change-Id: I4ccbd1ae3a909ecb4606ef18211d1b868f5cad86
Related-Change: Ic11662eb5c7176fbf422a6fc87a569928d6f85a1
"}, {'created': '2018-01-17 23:32:16.000000000', 'message': "slo: Send ETag header in 206 responses

Why weren't we doing that before?? The etag should be the same as for
GET/HEAD, and by sending it, we can assure resuming clients that they're
downlading the same object even if they didn't include an If-Match
header.

Change-Id: I4ccbd1ae3a909ecb4606ef18211d1b868f5cad86
Related-Change: Ic11662eb5c7176fbf422a6fc87a569928d6f85a1
"}]
commit_message:
slo: Send ETag header in 206 responses

Why weren't we doing that before?? The etag should be the same as for
GET/HEAD, and by sending it, we can assure resuming clients that they're
downlading the same object even if they didn't include an If-Match
header.

Change-Id: I4ccbd1ae3a909ecb4606ef18211d1b868f5cad86
Related-Change: Ic11662eb5c7176fbf422a6fc87a569928d6f85a1

commit_message:
Remove diskimages section from nodepool-launchers

Because nodepool-launcher don't build diskimages, we don't need to
carry this configuration. It help to remove duplicate data.

Also update tox.ini to test all versions of nodepool.yaml files.

Change-Id: Id4ed7b2d2bee15a057db837508c9c9a507725efc
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 27683, 'date': '2018-01-18 08:08:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-18 08:08:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-01-18 08:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-12 18:44:57.000000000', 'message': "Add ability to register non-official services

openstacksdk is in the business of being an SDK for OpenStack. While
it's tempting to support other services that people might want to run
alongside their OpenStack cloud and register in their keystone catalog,
doing so is just not feasible.

At the same time, the 95% case is that the openstacksdk will be used for
OpenStack services, so using entrpoints-based plugin loading as part of
normal usage incurs a startup cost that can be rather high (it's based
on the number of python packages installed on the system, not the number
of plugins for openstacksdk)

Add a method and a constructor parameter to Connection that allows
people to programmatically enable support for additional non-OpenStack
services. This introduce a new Service description class that maps
service_type, Proxy class and optional service_type aliases. A subclass
of Service could be provided by whoever is writing the Proxy class and
associated Resoure objects, or the base class can be instantiated with
type and proxy_class as arguments.

While doing this, rework the loading of the official OpenStack services
to use the Service descriptor objects. Add an OpenStackService subclass
which does the importlib searching of the openstack module tree for
proxy classes. This gets all of the module searching and loading into
the openstack.services module and out of Connection.

This should allow us to delete the metric service from the tree but
provide people who want to use the metric service with openstacksdk a
mechanism to do so. It also should provide a vehicle for people
developing new not-yet-official services to develop their Resource and
Proxy classes out of tree, and then move them in once they are official

Change-Id: I6d1e0c45026a2e7b3c42983df9c0565b1c501bc3
"}, {'created': '2018-01-12 23:29:21.000000000', 'message': "Add ability to register non-official services

openstacksdk is in the business of being an SDK for OpenStack. While
it's tempting to support other services that people might want to run
alongside their OpenStack cloud and register in their keystone catalog,
doing so is just not feasible.

At the same time, the 95% case is that the openstacksdk will be used for
OpenStack services, so using entrpoints-based plugin loading as part of
normal usage incurs a startup cost that can be rather high (it's based
on the number of python packages installed on the system, not the number
of plugins for openstacksdk)

Add a method and a constructor parameter to Connection that allows
people to programmatically enable support for additional non-OpenStack
services. This introduce a new Service description class that maps
service_type, Proxy class and optional service_type aliases. A subclass
of Service could be provided by whoever is writing the Proxy class and
associated Resoure objects, or the base class can be instantiated with
type and proxy_class as arguments.

While doing this, rework the loading of the official OpenStack services
to use the Service descriptor objects. Add an OpenStackService subclass
which does the importlib searching of the openstack module tree for
proxy classes. This gets all of the module searching and loading into
the openstack.services module and out of Connection.

This should allow us to delete the metric service from the tree but
provide people who want to use the metric service with openstacksdk a
mechanism to do so. It also should provide a vehicle for people
developing new not-yet-official services to develop their Resource and
Proxy classes out of tree, and then move them in once they are official

Change-Id: I6d1e0c45026a2e7b3c42983df9c0565b1c501bc3

commit_message:
Add ability to register non-official services

openstacksdk is in the business of being an SDK for OpenStack. While
it's tempting to support other services that people might want to run
alongside their OpenStack cloud and register in their keystone catalog,
doing so is just not feasible.

At the same time, the 95% case is that the openstacksdk will be used for
OpenStack services, so using entrpoints-based plugin loading as part of
normal usage incurs a startup cost that can be rather high (it's based
on the number of python packages installed on the system, not the number
of plugins for openstacksdk)

Add a method and a constructor parameter to Connection that allows
people to programmatically enable support for additional non-OpenStack
services. This introduce a new Service description class that maps
service_type, Proxy class and optional service_type aliases. A subclass
of Service could be provided by whoever is writing the Proxy class and
associated Resoure objects, or the base class can be instantiated with
type and proxy_class as arguments.

While doing this, rework the loading of the official OpenStack services
to use the Service descriptor objects. Add an OpenStackService subclass
which does the importlib searching of the openstack module tree for
proxy classes. This gets all of the module searching and loading into
the openstack.services module and out of Connection.

This should allow us to delete the metric service from the tree but
provide people who want to use the metric service with openstacksdk a
mechanism to do so. It also should provide a vehicle for people
developing new not-yet-official services to develop their Resource and
Proxy classes out of tree, and then move them in once they are official

Change-Id: I6d1e0c45026a2e7b3c42983df9c0565b1c501bc3

messages: [{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-01-05 16:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2018-01-17 18:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-01-18 19:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-05 16:31:16.000000000', 'message': 'PyMySQL 0.8.0 compat fix

In PyMySQL the "MULTI_STATEMENT" flag has been disabled
by default. (see PyMySQL/PyMySQL#590 )

Migration 98 had a single string with multiple statements
ran in a single execution.

Moving this to multiple executions of the same statements
allows the migration to succeed with the new behaviour.

Caused-By: PyMySQL/PyMySQL@c0aa3179406571592d3beb9d5a35badc4047cb79

Change-Id: I5f6d92f695c4c5830b8595b0cecbbafb426470a1
'}]
commit_message:
PyMySQL 0.8.0 compat fix

In PyMySQL the "MULTI_STATEMENT" flag has been disabled
by default. (see PyMySQL/PyMySQL#590 )

Migration 98 had a single string with multiple statements
ran in a single execution.

Moving this to multiple executions of the same statements
allows the migration to succeed with the new behaviour.

Caused-By: PyMySQL/PyMySQL@c0aa3179406571592d3beb9d5a35badc4047cb79

Change-Id: I5f6d92f695c4c5830b8595b0cecbbafb426470a1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-11 18:10:41.000000000', 'message': 'Handle swapping to a multiattach volume

Since swap volume doesn't attach the new volume using the
DriverVolumeBlockDevice.attach flow like normal attach or
server create, the new volume connection_info doesn't get
the "multiattach" value set in it, which is later read in
the virt driver's swap_volume method to build the disk device
config.

In the case of libvirt it relies on that multiattach flag
being set in the connection_info dict to set the 'shareable'
element on the LibvirtConfigGuestDisk object.

This change modifies the swap volume flow to perform the same
checks as in DriverVolumeBlockDevice._volume_attach. In this
change, for simplicity, it's just a copy/paste hack, and a TODO
is left to move this into common code later.

Part of blueprint multi-attach-volume

Change-Id: I173c404a54d1306e95c1cc3fbd651b137cb1c6aa

commit_message:
Handle swapping to a multiattach volume

Since swap volume doesn't attach the new volume using the
DriverVolumeBlockDevice.attach flow like normal attach or
server create, the new volume connection_info doesn't get
the "multiattach" value set in it, which is later read in
the virt driver's swap_volume method to build the disk device
config.

In the case of libvirt it relies on that multiattach flag
being set in the connection_info dict to set the 'shareable'
element on the LibvirtConfigGuestDisk object.

This change modifies the swap volume flow to perform the same
checks as in DriverVolumeBlockDevice._volume_attach. In this
change, for simplicity, it's just a copy/paste hack, and a TODO
is left to move this into common code later.

Part of blueprint multi-attach-volume

Change-Id: I173c404a54d1306e95c1cc3fbd651b137cb1c6aa

- Some repositories were not being excluded from evaluation
  for file/template updates. All appropriate exclusions are
  now implemented.

- If an OSA role repository did not have the required folder
  to copy rootwrap files into, the copy would fail and the

Change-Id: I628cd2c3156d118c17ca2f90d4ccf0bc5a080bbf

commit_message:
Fix sources-branch-updater and add docs

Problems resolved:

- Errors relating to 'etc' folders which did not exist in the
  target repositories have been eliminated.

- Some repositories were not being excluded from evaluation
  for file/template updates. All appropriate exclusions are
  now implemented.

- If an OSA role repository did not have the required folder
  to copy rootwrap files into, the copy would fail and the
  rootwrap files therefore be left out of the patch.

- The bad substitution command for the barbican api paste
  file adjustment has been fixed.

- When executed on Mac OS X, python2 is not found.

- Documentation is added to describe how to use the script
  to handle periodic SHA bumps.

Change-Id: I628cd2c3156d118c17ca2f90d4ccf0bc5a080bbf

commit_message:
Add initial tools for burndown charts

This tooling has been used several times for tracking large efforts
across many projects. This commit introduces it to the goal-tools
reporsitory and attempts to make it a bit more generic and not
specific to any one effort it was used for in the past.

Change-Id: I316cbd0fb9a98c5cc7cfdc6e4b96579e91d69271

We have switched to Zuul v3 now, this change does not apply anymore.

Learn on how to update your change with Zuul v3 at
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html .

Simplified:
* Job definitions can be in-repo; common job definitions are in
  openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs repository
* Job scheduling can be done in-repo for project specific changes,

Read the above mentioned document for finer details.

for Zuul v3 or abandon it.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:47:21.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

commit_message:
Temporarily copy unbound.log in test-results

In order to try and track down pervasive name resolution failures,
unbound has been configured to log errors to /var/log/unbound.log
recent images. Collect these along with the usual auxiliary logs so
we will be able to analyze them for clues following job completion.

Change-Id: Icf5ad32512a3dac74701fc99bd03d767746b1640

(2 comments)

I don't believe name conflict is something that can be automagically resolved in update_provider_tree at least not as we are currently imagining rp names.

So I'm not certain this change is warranted in this location. Happy to be told otherwise if there's something I'm missing.

(Another way of saying is: a name conflict really is an error, it's not a generation conflict, it is generation conflicts that we are concerned with in the discussion about provider-tree-wide retries.)"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-15 12:32:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

Good point, Chris.  I shall rethink this.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-15 15:03:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

Thanks for pointing this out, Chris.  I think you're right: we shouldn't change this code path.  I'm going to abandon this and just move the def of PlacementAPIConflict into the subsequent patch."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Per cdent comment, this is a bad idea.  The conflict exception (which is a good idea - for actual generation conflicts) is now introduced by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532564/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-10 16:14:18.000000000', 'message': 'Raise conflict exception on RP create 409

Per design [1], we want consumers of SchedulerReportClient to be able to
detect placement API conflict errors (HTTP 409), as distinct from other
errors.  Such consumers (the resource tracker) may respond to conflicts
by redriving the operation in progress, whereas other exceptions will be
allowed to bubble up.

In this change set, we introduce a new exception class,
PlacementAPIConflict, which will be the (base) class of exception raised
in response to placement 409s for which we want to allow this kind of
behavior.   We also update the _create_resource_provider helper in
SchedulerReportClient to do just that, raising
ResourceProviderCreateConflict (a subclass of the above) as appropriate.

Subsequent changes will implement similar behavior for other conflicts,
such as those caused by generation mismatches when updating provider
associations (traits, aggregates, etc.).

Ultimately, the resource tracker will trap PlacementAPIConflict while
attempting to sync placement from ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree,
and will respond by reinvoking that method and retrying the sync
operation.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-01-08-14.00.log.html#l-251

Change-Id: If1661900c14ef6c4fe29ecc67c04f741003a5318
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

commit_message:
Raise conflict exception on RP create 409

Per design [1], we want consumers of SchedulerReportClient to be able to
detect placement API conflict errors (HTTP 409), as distinct from other
errors.  Such consumers (the resource tracker) may respond to conflicts
by redriving the operation in progress, whereas other exceptions will be
allowed to bubble up.

In this change set, we introduce a new exception class,
PlacementAPIConflict, which will be the (base) class of exception raised
in response to placement 409s for which we want to allow this kind of
behavior.   We also update the _create_resource_provider helper in
SchedulerReportClient to do just that, raising
ResourceProviderCreateConflict (a subclass of the above) as appropriate.

Subsequent changes will implement similar behavior for other conflicts,
such as those caused by generation mismatches when updating provider
associations (traits, aggregates, etc.).

Ultimately, the resource tracker will trap PlacementAPIConflict while
attempting to sync placement from ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree,
and will respond by reinvoking that method and retrying the sync
operation.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-01-08-14.00.log.html#l-251

Change-Id: If1661900c14ef6c4fe29ecc67c04f741003a5318
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-01-14 14:08:47.000000000', 'message': "comp: Allow volume multiattach

Modify check_attach to accept multiple volume attachments. The patch
also allows to create multiple BDMs for a single volume.

The patch blocks booting from existing multiattach enabled volume by checking
the 'source_type' and 'destination_type' to be volume and 'boot_index'
to be zero in block_device_map.

APIImpact This patch allows to attach a volume to multiple VM instances
if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
"}, {'created': '2016-01-15 13:29:15.000000000', 'message': "WIP: comp: Allow volume multiattach

also allows to create multiple BDMs for a single volume.

The patch blocks booting from existing multiattach enabled volume by checking
the 'source_type' and 'destination_type' to be volume and 'boot_index'
to be zero in block_device_map.

"}, {'created': '2016-01-15 22:44:17.000000000', 'message': "WIP: comp: Allow volume multiattach

Modify check_attach to accept multiple volume attachments. The patch
also allows to create multiple BDMs for a single volume.

The patch blocks booting from existing multiattach enabled volume by checking
the 'source_type' and 'destination_type' to be volume and 'boot_index'
to be zero in block_device_map.

APIImpact This patch allows to attach a volume to multiple VM instances
if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
"}, {'created': '2016-01-16 10:09:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP: comp: Allow volume multiattach

Modify check_attach to accept multiple volume attachments. The patch
also allows to create multiple BDMs for a single volume.

The patch blocks booting from existing multiattach enabled volume by checking
the 'source_type' and 'destination_type' to be volume and 'boot_index'
to be zero in block_device_map.

APIImpact This patch allows to attach a volume to multiple VM instances
if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume

"}, {'created': '2016-01-21 18:17:52.000000000', 'message': "comp: Allow volume multiattach

This patch allows in the compute manager to attach a volume to multiple
VM instances if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

The change is needed as when we enable the 'multiattach' support in the API
in Newton in a mixed environment where we have both Mitaka and Newton
compute services the feature will work in the entire environment in a
homogen way depending on the API microversion.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
"}, {'created': '2016-01-28 09:47:41.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Allow multiple volume attachments

Add multiattach support to libvirt driver, by updating the
xml configuration info if the multiattach support is turned
on for a volume and set the virt driver capability
'support_multiattach' to true. This capability is set to false
for all the other drivers.

Also the attach function in nova/virt/block_device.py is updated
to call out to Cinder in case of each attachment request for
multiattach volumes, which is needed for Cinder in order to track
all attachments for a volume and be able to detach properly.

Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
"}, {'created': '2016-01-29 10:03:55.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Allow multiple volume attachments

for all the other drivers.

commit_message:
[libvirt] Allow multiple volume attachments

Add multiattach support to libvirt driver, by updating the
xml configuration info if the multiattach support is turned
on for a volume and set the virt driver capability
'support_multiattach' to true. This capability is set to false
for all the other drivers.

Also the attach function in nova/virt/block_device.py is updated
to call out to Cinder in case of each attachment request for
multiattach volumes, which is needed for Cinder in order to track
all attachments for a volume and be able to detach properly.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b

subject: fixed Unused views in Network Topology
messages:
[{'account_id': 27659, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-17 01:35:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27659, 'date': '2018-01-17 02:39:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1 Code-Review-1

This bug is more complicated than it initially seems, the delete functionality makes get http requests to these views.'}, {'account_id': 27659, 'date': '2018-01-18 20:34:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-17 01:34:53.000000000', 'message': 'fixed Unused views in Network Topology

Before this was fixed users could navigate to and be redirected
to these pages which serve no purpose other then that their urls
are used for delete operations. I have changed the code so
that the user is automatically redirected to the network_topology/index.
Because of this users will not find themselves on a page which is
useless for them and a page that they can not navigate out of
unless they use the back button.

Change-Id: Ia715075460446fc73175ac44bec144a029f633de
Fixes-Bug: #1718666
'}]
commit_message:
fixed Unused views in Network Topology

Before this was fixed users could navigate to and be redirected
to these pages which serve no purpose other then that their urls
are used for delete operations. I have changed the code so
that the user is automatically redirected to the network_topology/index.
Because of this users will not find themselves on a page which is
useless for them and a page that they can not navigate out of
unless they use the back button.

Change-Id: Ia715075460446fc73175ac44bec144a029f633de
Fixes-Bug: #1718666
